Rep. Dan Crenshaw, R.-Texas, introduced another bill the House will vote on Thursday that would prohibit Medicaid from covering gender transition procedures for anyone under the age of 18.

title: President's handpicked Kennedy Center board votes to rename it the 'Trump-Kennedy Center'
summary: The board of the Kennedy Center in Washington voted to rename it the Trump-Kennedy Center, a spokesperson for the arts institution said.“The unanimous vote recognizes that the current Chairman saved the institution from financial ruin and physical destruction,” Roma Daravi, the center’s vice president of public relations, said in a statement.
story: The board of the Kennedy Center in Washington voted to rename it the Trump-Kennedy Center, a spokesperson for the arts institution said.

“The unanimous vote recognizes that the current Chairman saved the institution from financial ruin and physical destruction,” Roma Daravi, the center’s vice president of public relations, said in a statement. “The new Trump Kennedy Center reflects the unequivocal bipartisan support for America’s cultural center for generations to come.”

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said on X:"Congratulations to President Donald J. Trump, and likewise, congratulations to President Kennedy, because this will be a truly great team long into the future! The building will no doubt attain new levels of success and grandeur."
The news prompted swift backlash from some members of the Kennedy family, including some who suggested the change might not be lawful.

Former Rep. Joseph Kennedy III, a grandnephew of the late president, said in a statement: “The Kennedy Center is a living memorial to a fallen president and named for President Kennedy by federal law. It can no sooner be renamed than can someone rename the Lincoln Memorial, no matter what anyone says.”

Kerry Kennedy, a niece of the late president and the sister of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., also condemned the change, writing on X, “President Trump and his administration have spent the past year repressing free expression, targeting artists, journalists, and comedians, and erasing the history of Americans whose contributions made our nation better and more just.”

She added: “President Kennedy proudly stood for justice, peace, equality, dignity, diversity, and compassion for those who suffer. President Trump stands in opposition to these values, and his name should not be placed alongside President Kennedy’s.”

Efforts to rename the Kennedy Center could run into legal hurdles, experts told NBC News in July, after Republican lawmakers introduced several proposals in Congress to rename it in honor of Trump or first lady Melania Trump.
Rep. Joyce Beatty, D-Ohio, an ex-officio member of the board, disputed the account that the vote was “unanimous.”
“For the record. This was not unanimous. I was muted on the call and not allowed to speak or voice my opposition to this move,” she wrote on X.
Trump told reporters later Thursday at the White House that he was "surprised" and "honored" by the board's vote.
"This was brought up by one of the very distinguished board members, and they voted on it, and there’s a lot of board members, and they voted unanimously. So I was very honored," he said.

Beatty told reporters at the Capitol later Thursday that the question of renaming the Kennedy Center was not on the agenda provided to board members before the meeting and that she was surprised when it came up.

"I said, 'I have something to say,' and I was muted, and as I continued to try to unmute to ask questions and voiced my opposition to this, I received a note saying that I would not be unmuted," she told reporters, adding, "I was cut off."
In a statement, Daravi pushed back against Beatty's assertion that she was not able to speak up in the meeting, saying Beatty was granted "the privilege" to listen in.

"The entire board was invited to attend in person and the privilege of listening in on the meeting was granted to all members, even those without a vote, such as ex-officio member Joyce Beatty," Daravi said.

The original laws that guided the creation of the Kennedy Center during the Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson administrations specifically prohibited renaming the building. It would take an act of Congress to change that now.

“Federal law established the Center as a memorial to President Kennedy and prohibits changing its name without Congressional action,” six of the Democratic lawmakers who are ex officio board members at the Kennedy Center, including Beatty and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, said in a joint statement Thursday.

Sen. Shelley Moore Capito, R-W.Va., another ex-officio member of the Kennedy Center board who did not get a vote on the name change, told NBC News on Thursday night that “the Kennedy Center, in my view, is the Kennedy Center.”

Capito said she was not sure if the name change would require legislation. “I honestly don’t know," she said. "I would assume so, because it’s mentioned more than a few times as the Kennedy Center in legislation. So I would imagine that’s the case.”

After Rep. Mike Simpson, R-Idaho, introduced an amendment this year to legislation that would rename the building after Melania Trump, he said that she not been aware of his efforts before his public introduction of the amendment.
Since the start of his second term, the president has sought to reshape the Kennedy Center and its programming.

In February, he abruptly fired members of the center’s board and installed himself as chair, writing on Truth Social at the time, “At my direction, we are going to make the Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., GREAT AGAIN.”
In the post, he specifically cited his disapproval of the center’s decision to host drag shows.

Weeks later, the newly installed members of the Kennedy Center board, including second lady Usha Vance, White House chief of staff Susie Wiles and Trump advisers Dan Scavino and Sergio Gor, officially elected Trump as board chair.
Later this year, ahead of Pride Month, the Kennedy Center informed some Pride event organizers that they would no longer be able to host some Pride gatherings.

Trump this month hosted the Kennedy Center Honors ceremony, an annual event honoring legends in music, movies, television and culture. And just last month, the Kennedy Center was the site of FIFA’s World Cup draw, an event attended and oft-touted by Trump.

Trump in the past has referred to the cultural institution as the “Trump/Kennedy Center,” writing on Truth Social in August, “GREAT Nominees for the TRUMP/KENNEDY CENTER, whoops, I mean, KENNEDY CENTER.”

title: After Trump promised 'no new wars,' Venezuela could test MAGA's tolerance, analysts say
summary: President Donald Trump’s political base has offered little resistance to his escalating pressure campaign on Venezuela.
story: President Donald Trump’s political base has offered little resistance to his escalating pressure campaign on Venezuela, even as he edges closer to the kind of military confrontation he has long criticized elsewhere.

After he won last year, Trump declared in his victory speech that he was “not going to start a war, I’m going to stop wars,” praising the “strong” U.S. military that, "ideally, we don’t have to use.” And this year he denounced decades of U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East, decrying “Western interventionists” who had given other countries “lectures on how to live.”

That stance has been tested as his administration seized an oil tanker, with Trump suggesting the U.S. could carry out land operations aimed at removing Venezuelan President Nicolás  Maduro. The administration’s campaign has already resulted in more than 26 boat strikes, killing at least 98 people, including a “double tap” strike now under congressional scrutiny.

On Tuesday, the president said he was ordering a “total and complete blockade” of sanctioned oil tankers to and from Venezuela, accusing its government of using oil revenue to finance illicit operations, such as “drug terrorism.”

The unfolding campaign has become a test of whether Trump’s political coalition will tolerate the use of force so long as it stays targeted and does not produce American casualties, political analysts and administration allies said in interviews with NBC News.
“MAGA loves blowing up the boats,” said Rachel Bovard, vice president of programs at the Conservative Partnership Institute. “They do not want a land war with Venezuela.”
Add NBC News to Google
Add NBC News to Google

While “America First” loyalists have questioned Trump’s focus on other foreign issues — including Ukraine, Israel and a slew of peace efforts across the Middle East, Africa and Southeast Asia — they appear to be holding their fire on Venezuela for now.

Justin Logan, director of defense and foreign policy studies at the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank based in Washington, said the absence of any substantial backlash reflects not ideological agreement with the policy itself, but the low political cost of the administration’s actions so far.

“You can run wild and crazy foreign policies when the costs are low, and the costs here have been low thus far,” he said. “But if you entered into a regime change conflict, the cost would go up, and the attention and dissent would go up.”

Asked by reporters this month how an invasion or land strikes in Venezuela  — which would raise the risk of a prolonged war and potentially involve U.S. troops — would align with the president’s MAGA base, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters that Trump has been clear that he does not want a protracted war.

“He’s been very clear about that. He wants peace,” Leavitt said. “He also wants to see the end of illegal drugs being trafficked into the United States and taking the lives of hundreds of thousands of Americans across our country, and he’s thinking about that every day here at the White House, with every drug boat that is taken out by this administration.”
Reached for comment for this story, the White House framed the Venezuela actions as a fulfillment of the president’s electoral promises on drug enforcement.

“On the campaign trail, President Trump promised to take on the cartels — and he has taken unprecedented action to stop the scourge of narcoterrorism that has resulted in the needless deaths of innocent Americans,” White House deputy press secretary Anna Kelly said in a statement. “All of these decisive strikes have been against designated narcoterrorists bringing deadly poison to our shores, and the President will continue to use every element of American power to stop drugs from flooding into our country.”
Some Trump allies are wondering what Venezuela has to do with his administration’s goals.

“The question that I have is, who is asking for this?” said one conservative foreign policy expert, who spoke candidly on the condition of anonymity. “I don’t feel a great upswell of MAGA nationalism, saying we have to dislodge Maduro, or saying stop the cocaine traffickers.”

Some critics of the administration’s approach say there is at minimum a coherent historical argument for action, pointing to Trump’s National Security Strategy for 2025, which promised to reassert the Monroe Doctrine “after years of neglect" by asserting the U.S.’s role in maintaining stability in the Western Hemisphere.

“While I’m against the strikes on Venezuela, it’s at least somewhat coherent that this is within our national interest,” said Curt Mills, a conservative and policy analyst. “This is within our homeland. These people are bringing drugs. The Monroe Doctrine is at least rooted in some sort of history.”

Yet Mills, the executive director of The American Conservative magazine, said that if the administration were to try to remove Maduro, it could ignite a debate among conservatives that has not yet fully broken out into the open, one he said could eclipse disputes over Ukraine and Iran.

“The argument against toppling dictators in Latin America is going to be one that is more divisive on the right than, say, caring about who controls the Donbas, or caring about the Iranians enriching to 2%,” he said.

There may be material public support for military actions aimed at preventing drugs from entering the country. During the last presidential campaign, NBC News polling found that among GOP policy proposals tested, using the military to stop illegal drugs from entering the U.S. from Mexico was the most popular, both among Republicans and voters overall.
Logan said the administration’s rhetoric on Venezuela has offered little in the way of telling what comes next, however.

“The Western Hemisphere is where we build out from, it’s the first order of business in our security,” he said. “But what that means in practice is less clear. My sense is that people are all singing from the same hymn, but it’s not clear what comes next.”
That ambiguity has allowed Trump to occupy both sides of the debate, maintaining a diplomatic opening even as he repeatedly threatens force.

“He’s trying ... to project himself as tough to Maduro,” said Patrick Hulme, an assistant professor of law and political science at the University of Florida. “He’s bargaining with him. He’s trying to make Maduro think that, ‘I’m Trump, I’m crazy, I’m a madman. I might actually do it.’”
In a recent interview with Politico, Trump declined to discuss his military strategy but said that he wanted the Venezuelan people “to be respected” and that Maduro’s “days are numbered.”

At the same time, Trump has spoken to Maduro in recent weeks. The conversation was described by a source familiar with the call as “not great, not terrible — decent,” and Trump has appeared to leave open the door to further communication.
“It’s weird,” Mills said. "Bush was not having conversations with Saddam. That is what’s both stranger and more optimistic about this."
Logan said there still appears to be some uncertainty about the policy’s objectives, including at the highest level.
“And maybe even uncertainty in the mind of the president himself,” he added. He pointed to Trump’s comments after the tanker seizure, when he was asked what would happen to the oil.

“‘We’ll keep it, I guess,’” Logan quoted the president as saying. “Which implies that this is not being drawn up with a great deal of specificity. There’s an anti-Maduro policy. What end state that seeks and the costs that will be paid to pursue it, seem to me, undetermined.”
“At some point, the cup and the lip have to meet,” said a political operative close to the administration.
Even so, the rhetoric has grown sharper.

In October, Trump said he had authorized the CIA to carry out covert lethal action in Venezuela, citing narcotics trafficking and repeating his claim that the country had emptied its prisons into the United States — an allegation Venezuela denies.

Asked about the timing of possible land strikes, he said last week that they would happen “pretty soon" and suggested that similar actions could extend to other countries if drug targets were identified. He declined to say whether the U.S. would seize additional Venezuelan oil following the tanker seizure last week.
The administration has said the tanker is used to transport sanctioned oil from Venezuela and Iran. It also announced sanctions against six more ships and several members of Maduro’s family.

Democratic lawmakers and Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., have expressed concern that the seizure, and in particular the “double-tap” strike in September on an alleged drug trafficking boat, could escalate tensions, raising questions about the president’s war powers and the legal authority underpinning operations, especially the absence of explicit congressional authorization.

Lawmakers in both parties have sought briefings and called for transparency around the strikes. Congress’s annual defense authorization bill passed this week with a provision that would restrict the defense secretary’s travel budget until he provides House and Senate committees with “unedited video” of the strikes.
The question has become more than just political, analysts argue, as actions escalate.

“We’re all wondering what one person will decide about the highest of high politics, the question of war and peace for the United States. And the Congress appears complacent and powerless,” Logan said. “Trump isn’t even going through the motions of pretending the Congress has a role to play.”
Asked during a late October roundtable at the White House whether he would seek a declaration of war against drug cartels, which would need to be passed by Congress, Trump suggested he would not.

“I don’t think we’re going to necessarily ask for a declaration of war,” he said. “I think we’re just going to kill people that are bringing drugs into our country. OK, we’re gonna kill them. You know, they’re gonna be, like, dead.”

title: 'Heated Rivalry' Episode 5 Release Time: When to Watch on HBO Max
summary: "Heated Rivalry" is expected to keep raising the temperature as the Canadian series moves on to Episode 5. Find out the exact release time and how to watch.
story: "Heated Rivalry" has HBO Max viewers hooked.

Ever since the romantic drama premiered on Nov. 28, fans of the new series have been eager to find out how the six-part story will end, and where it will leave Shane Hollaner (Hudson Williams) and Ilya Rozanov's (Connor Storrie) romance.
Before the latest episode drops, we're sharing everything you need to know to tune in.
What Time Will Episode 5 of 'Heated Rivalry' Come Out?
Episode 5, which is titled “I’ll Believe in Anything,” will premiere on HBO Max at 12 a.m. PT on Friday, Dec. 19 and 9 p.m. PT on Thursday, Dec. 18.
What Is ‘Heated Rivalry’ About?
"Heated Rivalry" is inspired by Rachel Reid’s book series “Game Changers.”
The HBO Max show tells the story of two hockey players and NHL rivals, Canadian Shane Hollander and Russian Ilya Rozanov.
While following Shane and Ilya over the course of several years, viewers get an intimate look at their personal and professional lives, which intertwine when they become romantically involved.
While speaking with TODAY.com, Reid said the experience of having her work adapted into a TV series has been "a dream."

"And you can even see with the way that the promotion of the show is going, everybody’s still mentioning the book, mentioning me, crediting me for so much. It’s really nice. I wasn’t expecting any of that," she said.
What Happened in ‘Heated Rivalry’ Episode 4?
Episode 4 of "Heated Rivalry" leaves Shane and Ilya with other people and pining for each other.
As his feelings for Ilya grow, Shane seems to run from them, straight into the arms of a Hollywood star named Rose Landry (Sophie Nélisse).
The episode ends with Shane and Ilya locking eyes at a club. Shane is with Rose; Ilya is dancing with a stranger. Their gaze holds so much – and it might be translated into words come Episode 5.

title: Ariana Grande Wrote Teyana Taylor a Note Ahead of the Golden Globes. What It Says
summary: Ariana Grande wrote Teyana Taylor a note ahead of the 2026 Golden Globes. Read what it says in full.
story: Ariana Grande is letting Teyana Taylor know she's proud to be competing against her at the 2026 Golden Globes.
Taylor, 35, shared a pic Dec. 17 in her Instagram Story that showed a bouquet of flowers Grande 32, sent to her.

Grande, who was nominated in the best supporting actress category for her role in "Wicked: For Good," included a sweet notecard for Taylor, who earned a nomination in the same category for her role in "One Battle After Another."
"Teyana, Hi and congratulations on this well, well deserved moment and nomination! I’m so honored to be in your company in this moment!" Grande wrote.

“I absolutely loved 'One Battle After Another," she continued, "and I’m so excited to tell you more in person but I just wanted to say you are so brilliant and I’m so excited to share this moment and nomination with you."
She signed the card, "Love Always, Ariana."

Taylor added her own message for Grande in her post, writing, "This is so sweet @arianagrande, Thank you. Your message made this moment even more special for me. I’m so honored to share this space with you as well, and I’m deeply grateful for your kindness and support. See you soon.”

The milestone marks Taylor's first Golden Globe nomination. Her portrayal of a political revolutionary in "One Battle After Another" has already earned her awards from the Chicago Film Critics Association, Los Angeles Film Critics Association, Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Awards, among other groups.

Grande previously earned a Golden Globe nomination last year for her portray of Glinda in "Wicked." She also earned an Academy Award nomination, a Screen Actors Guild Award nominations and a BAFTA nomination for her role.

Grande and Taylor both face tough competition at the 2026 Golden Globes. Also nominated in their category are Emily Blunt for “The Smashing Machine," Elle Fanning for “Sentimental Value," Inga Ibsdotter Lilleaas for “Sentimental Value" and Amy Madigan for “Weapons.”

title: 'Emily in Paris' Season 5 Ending Explained — Plus, Where Emily Might Be Going Next
summary: What happens in the Emily in Paris Season 5 finale? Here's an ending explainer for Emily in Paris Season 5.
story: Spoilers for Season 5 of "Emily in Paris" ahead.
From Rome to Paris to Venice and back to the City of Light, Season 5 of "Emily in Paris" takes viewers on a whirlwind European adventure.
The hit Netflix series returned with 10 new episodes on Dec. 18 and left many fans hungry for more with an exciting cliffhanger.
Whether you've already binge-watched Season 5 or are simply looking for a quick recap, we're breaking down everything you need to know about the magnifique season finale.
Marcello Hosts a Fashion Show in Venice
After stepping away from his family's company, Marcello (Eugenio Franceschini) branches out to create his own clothing line. In the season finale, he hosts a fashion show in Venice.

Mother nature intervenes and causes Marcello and the Agence Grateau team to improvise when their Venetian event venue is filled with acqua alta (water from the high tides). All's well that ends well, though, since the team decides to stock up on rain boots for the models and guests.

When Marcello's mother shows up unexpectedly, everyone's nervous. She had recently served him with legal papers after he started his own company. Surprisingly, Marcello's mom is thrilled with the fashion show and says it's time for her to step down so Marcello can take over their family's company. She then introduces him as the new head of the House of Muratori.

Marcello is psyched at the prospect of running his family’s company and says his mother requested that Emily stay on as their marketing specialist. This would require her to leave Paris and move to Italy, however, so she needs some time to think about it.
Nicolas Proposes to Mindy

When Emily loses her passport, she goes through Marcello’s bag to look for it and finds an engagement ring. She assumes that he’s going to propose to her and immediately tells Mindy (Ashley Park), who asks if she’s excited. Emily says yes but admits that it seems early. Still, she says it feels “right” and loves that Marcello lives in Paris now.

While they’re out to dinner, Emily thinks Marcello is about to propose, but it’s a false alarm. Later, they go on a romantic gondola ride with Mindy and Nicolas (Paul Forman) and Marcello pulls out a ring. Emily says she loves Marcello but can’t marry him because she can’t leave Paris to move to Italy.
“It’s not my life!” she exclaims.
“It’s also not your ring,” he says.
Marcello then explains that he was holding the ring for Nicolas, who proceeds to propose to Mindy. She gladly accepts.
Emily and Marcello Break Up
After their awkward non-proposal, Emily and Marcello talk and she apologizes for her reaction, saying it was "presumptuous" of her to think that he was ready to propose.

Marcello says he has been thinking about taking the next step in their relationship in the future and she says she's been thinking about it too. Still, she's not ready to leave her life in Paris behind.
"I love Paris too, but only because you are there," Marcello replies, adding that he belongs in Italy.
"I know. I wish I could be there with you," she says.
"But you can't," he says.
"Its' a beautiful dream but it's just not mine," she says.
Alfie Learns About Mindy's Engagement and He's Not Thrilled
Throughout the season, Mindy and Alfie (Lucien Laviscount) have been exploring their unexpected romantic connection.

Emily and Mindy hit a rough patch in their friendship when Emily learned that her best friend was sneaking around with her ex-boyfriend behind her back, but they've since smoothed things over. And besides, Mindy got back together with Nicolas and is now engaged to him.

In the finale, Alfie runs into Emily and Mindy in Paris and sees the ring on Mindy's finger. Emily shares the good news and Alfie asks when Mindy was going to tell him. She says she just did, but he says Emily did, not Mindy. Emily tries to defuse the awkward moment but Alfie tells Mindy he thinks she's making a mistake marrying Nicolas.
When he leaves, Emily asks Mindy if she still has feelings for Alfie and her long pause says it all.
Princess Jane Saves Agence Grateau

When Sylvie (Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu) learns that her husband, Laurent (Arnaud Binard), ran two nightclubs into the ground and borrowed against her mother's property, she's furious. She then discovers that she's still financially responsible for his debts, even if they get a divorce.

Since the bankruptcy court is coming for all of Laurent's assets, including Sylvie's assets (her savings, her apartment and her company), Sylvie warns Luc (Bruno Gouery) and Julien (Samuel Arnold) that they should look for new jobs since she's not sure if Agence Grateau will be sold or liquidated.

When they're back in Paris, Sylvie is pleasantly surprised to hear that Emily declined the job working for Marcello's family business. However, she warns her that things might change at Agence Grateau and explains that the PR firm was in financial trouble.
To help keep them afloat, Sylvie brought in an equity partner: Princess Jane (Minnie Driver), her old friend.

Emily is confused because Jane had made it clear that she didn't have a lot of money when they had met in Italy. After her husband died unexpectedly, though, she learned that he left her their mansion and she's about to come into a lot of money. Now, Jane is the co-head of Agence Grateau.
Gabriel Invites Emily to Visit Him in Greece

Earlier this season, Emily connected Gabriel (Lucas Bravo) with a wealthy hotel developer who ended up offering him a job as his private chef on his yacht. Gabriel then left his restaurant to travel the world with the man.

In the finale, Gabriel learns that he has a bit of a break from work. Sylvie then texts him to say that Emily is back in Paris and single. Emily had previously told Gabriel to send her a postcard, so he mails her one and invites her to join him in Greece.

title: How Rob Reiner Rediscovered Love with Wife Michele: Marriage Became 'Better and Better'
summary: Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were married 36 years. He revealed how they met and why he changed the ending of "When Harry Met Sally."
story: Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were married for 36 years — a romance that began after he struggled to find love after his divorce.

It came to a horrific last weekend. The couple was found dead in their Los Angeles home on Sunday, Dec. 14, and appeared to have died from stab wounds, a source close to the Reiner family told NBC News.
Their cause of death was multiple sharp force injuries, according to the medical examiner's report, released on Tuesday, Dec. 17.
Nick Reiner, their son, has been arrested and booked on suspicion of murdering his parents.
Reiner, who was 78 when he died, said that before meeting his second wife, he didn’t think he’d find love again.
The actor and director was previously married to actress and director Penny Marshall. They wed in 1971 and divorced in 1981.

The aftermath of that split and his struggles to find a new partner were his inspiration for making “When Harry Met Sally” — the beloved romantic comedy he directed, starring Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan.

''I was in the middle of my single life. I'd been divorced for a while. I'd been out a number of times, all these disastrous, confusing relationships one after another,” Reiner told The New York Times in 1989.
As a single man, he was making “an utter mess” of his personal life and wanted to make a movie about what men and women go through, he added in an interview with People.

Reiner called himself the “prototype for Harry” in the movie, a man shocked by his divorce and unable to find love: “I couldn't see how I would get with anybody ever again. It became the basis for the film,” the director told AARP in 2014.
But about three-quarters of the way through making the movie, he met his second wife-to-be, the friend of a colleague.
The love story began when Reiner told Barry Sonnenfeld, the film’s cinematographer, about the struggles in his personal life.
“And he says to me, 'I know this girl. Her name is Michele Singer, and you're going to marry her.' And I said, 'What, are you nuts?'” Reiner recalled to The New York Times.
But when she came to the set one day, he was quickly smitten.

“I'll never forget it. It was a scene on a stoop in front of a brownstone. Billy and Meg are having an argument. And I look over, and I see this girl, and whoo! I was attracted immediately. And Barry says, 'That's Michele.' I said, 'That's Michele?'”
After meeting her, Reiner thought, "I see how this could work again," he told AARP.
Michele Singer was a photographer, producer and actress. The couple married in May 1989 and had three children.
"As you go along, the relationship becomes better and better because you really become best friends. And that has happened,” Reiner told AARP about his second marriage.
“She has helped raise me. The thing I talk about, how women show you what's important, she has done for me."
In 2024, Reiner revealed the love story with his wife inspired him to change the ending of “When Harry Met Sally.”

The original script had the characters Harry Burns and Sally Albright going their separate ways rather than the happier finale fans know — Harry professing his love on New Year’s Eve, telling Sally he wanted to spend the rest of his life with her and the pair becoming a couple.
“It was going to be the two of them seeing each other after years, talking, and then walking away from each other,” he said on “Who’s Talking to Chris Wallace.”
“I met my wife, Michele… while we were making the film, and I changed the ending.”
Meg Ryan paid tribute to Reiner and his wife on Instagram, writing, "Oh how we will miss this man. Thank you, Rob and Michelle, for the way you believe in true love, in fairy tales, and in laughter."
Reiner also directed “The Princess Bride,” “A Few Good Men” and “This Is Spinal Tap.”
Family friend Maria Shriver remembered the couple as "two deeply talented, kind, fun, loving, good, patriotic people who loved each other deeply."

title: 'Emily in Paris' Season 4 Recap: 11 Things to Remember Before Watching Season 5
summary: What to remember about Season Four of "Emily in Paris" before Season Five premieres. Read this recap to refresh yourself on Emily in Paris Season 4.
story: After a disastrous surprise wedding and a shocking pregnancy announcement in the Season 3 finale, "Emily in Paris" had a lot of loose ends to tie up in Season 4.

Luckily, the hit Netflix series didn't disappoint viewers. Throughout Season 4, "Emily in Paris" explored the fallout of Camille (Camille Razat) and Gabriel's (Lucas Bravo) failed nuptials and gave fans exactly what they've been begging for: an Emily (Lily Collins) and Gabriel romance.
Of course, the action-packed season also had plenty of ups and downs and featured heartbreak, a new love interest for Emily and lots of drama at Agence Grateau.
Just in time for Season 5, we're recapping what went down in Season 4 so you're ready to binge-watch the new season when it hits Netflix on Dec. 18.
Camille Was Never Pregnant. Now She's Adopting a Child.
After calling off her wedding to Gabriel, Camille goes missing. When Emily tracks her down, Camille returns to Paris and decides to pursue a relationship with Sofia (Melia Kreiling).
Gabriel lets Sofia move into the apartment he shared with Camille while the new couple looks for their own place to live. They later move into the apartment next door to Gabriel.
Camille visits a doctor and learns that she was never actually pregnant (her test had been a false positive). She waits a while to tell Gabriel, but eventually does.

While hanging out one day, Camille asks Gabriel to visit a priest with her. She asks the priest about adoption and Gabriel confronts her afterwards, saying they both deserve to start a family with someone they're in love with, and not hold onto each other.
At the end of the season, Camille announces that she's going to adopt a child on her own.
Gabriel and Emily Dated and Broke Up
Once the dust settles after Camille and Gabriel's failed wedding, Emily is left to decide if she wants to get back together with Alfie (Lucien Laviscount) or pursue a relationship with Gabriel.

At a masquerade ball, Alfie believes he's talking to Emily, but it's actually a woman who's dressed in the same outfit. He kisses her, then realizes it's not Emily. At the same time, he spots the real Emily leaving the masquerade ball with Gabriel.

Emily and Gabriel start to date each other. When Christmastime arrives, Emily is excited to go home to Chicago for a visit, but the weather has other plans. She ends up staying in France and is invited to fête the holidays with Camille's family and Gabriel. While there, Gabriel asks Emily to go skiing with him and Camille.

Gabriel worries about Camille and the baby when she suddenly speeds away on the slopes and leaves Emily, a novice skier, to fend for herself. She ends up falling and is rescued by a handsome Italian man named Marcello (Eugenio Franceschini).

When Emily grows frustrated that Gabriel abandoned her, he defends himself and says Camille is having his baby so, of course, he has to watch out for her. Emily suggests that she's only ever going to be seen as his "mistress" and is tired of them trying to make their relationship work.

Emily cuts her trip short and returns to Paris, where she runs into Alfie, who is about to go to a church service with his new girlfriend and her family. Emily is crushed that she's lost out on two great guys.
Sylvie Spoke Out Against Louis de Leon

Earlier in her career, Sylvie worked for Louis de Leon (Pierre Deny), the CEO of fictional luxury brand JVMA. In Season 4, she decides to speak out about an inappropriate incident that occurred between her and Louis when she worked as his assistant.

Sylvie is hesitant to do so at first, but a reporter asks her to participate in a story she’s working on to expose de Leon’s behavior, which included a “long history of promising promotions in exchange for sexual favors.”
The article has ripple effects when de Leon pulls funding for the club Sylvie’s husband, Laurent, owns.
Mindy and Nicolas Broke Up

Mindy (Ashley Park) and Nicolas (Paul Forman) have plenty of ups and downs while dating this season. For starters, he isn’t thrilled when she starts working for a club that requires her to go topless.

But the story exposing his father Louis de Leon's inappropriate behavior puts a bigger wedge between Nicolas and Mindy. Mindy encourages her boyfriend to do the right thing and he later announces that he told the board he won't work for JVMA as long as his father is still employed there.
When Nicolas asks Mindy to attend an event where she'd need to take photos with his father in public, she doesn't feel comfortable doing so.
While preparing for Eurovision, Mindy and her group do a photoshoot. Photographers encourage her and her ex-boyfriend, Benoit (Kevin Dias) to pose for a sultry photo where they are almost kissing.

When the photos go public, Nicolas asks Mindy to drop out of the Eurovision competition since his family's reputation is on the line. Nicolas then posts her song online, which goes against Eurovision rules and disqualifies Mindy and her band from competing. Mindy then tells Emily that she and Nicolas have broken up.

When she visits Emily in Rome, Mindy is inspired to sing a song in public. Someone films it and it goes viral. The Chinese show Mindy once appeared on reaches out to her to ask her to serve as a judge and perform her song.
Laurent’s Daughter Genevieve Started Working for Sylvie and She Set Her Eyes on Gabriel

Sylvie (Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu) and her husband Laurent (Arnaud Binard) have an unconventional marriage and often take on new lovers. In Season 4, Laurent’s daughter from another relationship, Geneviève (Thalia Besson), stays with the couple over the holidays.

Geneviève is a recent college graduate and has an interview with a woman who used to run Vogue Paris. Sylvie offers to put a good word in for her but it backfires when the woman says Sylvie should hire Geneviève if she likes her so much.
Begrudgingly, Sylvie does just that and asks Emily to keep an eye on her. Geneviève warms up to Emily, a fellow American, quickly and is rather intrigued when she meets Gabriel.

While filming a PR piece at his restaurant, Gabriel and Emily have an argument after she asks why he didn’t tell her that Camille wasn’t pregnant. He starts speaking quickly in French and she has no idea what he’s saying. Geneviève lies to Emily while translating and says Gabriel said he didn’t want to see her again.

Geneviève moves into Emily and Gabriel’s building and she invites him to a housewarming party she’s throwing. While playing beer pong, Geneviève kisses Gabriel. He later tells her he wants to keep things professional and isn’t interested in pursuing anything romantic with her.
Emily Started Dating Marcello
Emily runs into Marcello in Paris, sparks fly and he invites her to visit him in Italy. Sylvie is determined to book Marcello's family company as a client for Agence Grateau and crashes Emily's trip.

Marcello is annoyed and thinks that Emily only came to Rome to talk business so he gives her the cold shoulder. Marcello's family later agrees to a meeting with Emily and Sylvie. In the end, they ask Emily to run the account and stay in Rome.
Emily smooths things over with Marcello and they both look forward to spending more time together.
Luke's Girlfriend Isn't a Michelin Star Reviewer

Gabriel dreams of earning a Michelin star for his restaurant. Luc (Bruno Gouery) has been doing everything he can to make that happen by enlisting the help of his former girlfriend Marianne (Laurence Gormezano), who works as a Michelin star reviewer.
Marianne leads Luc and Gabriel to believe that a star is within reach, but then they discover that she was actually fired from Michelin a year ago.

The truth comes out while Sylvie, Laurent, Marianne and Luc are out to dinner. Marianne tries to get the meal comped since she works for Michelin, but another Michelin reviewer stops that from happening when he announces that she was actually previously fired for insider dining.
Gabriel Finally Got His Michelin Star

Despite Marianne's lies, Gabriel was in fact on the radar of the Michelin star team. In the finale, Geneviève tells him that he earned a star for his restaurant. The chef is thrilled and calls Emily to leave a voicemail so she knows the good news.
Laurent Went Into Business with Sylvie's Mother

Laurent spends a lot of time in Saint-Tropez working at his club. When he decides to expand his business and open a club in Paris, he gets funding from Louis de Leon. When that falls through, Sylvie asks her mother to help find a location for Laurent's club.
As it turns out, Sylvie's mom used to run her own club and she's willing to let Laurent use the space for his club.
Julien Returned to Agence Grateau

Julien (Samuel Arnold) jumps ship to work for JVMA, but realizes he made a mistake after working there for a while. He then makes amends with Sylvie and returns to work with Sylvie, Luc and Emily at Agence Grateau.
Sylvie Decided to Open an Office in Rome and Asked Emily to Run It
After Sylvie and Emily convince Marcello's family to give Agence Grateau a chance, Sylvie asks Emily to stay in Paris to run the account and head up a new Rome location of the PR agency.
Mindy tells Alfie and Gabrielle the big news and Alfie encourages Gabriel to chase after Emily.
Meanwhile, Sylvie seems interested in sticking around Rome for a while since she's reignited a love affair with an old flame.

title: Who Won ‘Survivor’ Season 49? A Recap of the Finale
summary: Read a recap of the "Survivor" Season 49 finale and find out who won the $1 million prize. Plus see who will be returning for Season 50.
story: Warning; Major spoilers ahead for the “Survivor” Season 49 finale…

In a teaser for the “Survivor” Season 49 finale, host Jeff Probst said, “This has been one of the most unpredictable games we have ever seen.” But did the five remaining castaways deliver an epic ending to the season?

When the three-hour Season 49 finale began on Wednesday, Dec. 17, there were five contestants hoping to win the title of “sole ‘Survivor’” and the $1 million prize: Kristina Mills, Rizo Velovic, Sage Ahrens-Nichols, Savannah Louie and Sophi "Soph" Balerdi.

The final five still had a couple Immunity Challenges, the controversial Fire-Making Challenge and Final Tribal Council to get through before the jury voted for a winner. Plus, the after show revealed which two castaways will return for the historic Season 50, arriving Wednesday, Feb. 25,  2026.
Read on to find out everything that happened in the Season 49 finale, including who was crowned the winner, below.
1st  Immunity Challenge

After Soph found an advantage in the jungle to help her in the Immunity Challenge, she learned from Probst at the challenge that half of her puzzle pieces were already placed in the correct spots. But Soph instantly fell behind during the first portion of the challenge and struggled to crawl through the mud.

Meanwhile, Savannah sped through nearly every portion and quickly completed the puzzle, giving her a record-tying fourth Immunity Challenge win and guaranteeing her a spot in the final four.  She also won the reward and chose to take Sage to the Sanctuary to enjoy steak and potatoes.
In her confessional, Savannah smiled wide as she celebrated her win and pointed out how she has been able to outlast her foes all season long.
1st Tribal Council

Back at camp, Kristina — who assumed Savannah, Soph and Rizo would vote together given that they've been a strong trio for most of the game — pitched voting out Sage to Soph and Rizo. During the reward meal, Sage suggested to Savannah that the better move was to vote out Kristina since she could beat anyone in the Fire-Making Challenge. Thus, the Tres Leches alliance was at a stalemate going into Tribal Council.

After a back-and-forth between Kristina and Sage at Tribal Council where they both explained why the other was a threat, it was time to vote. Rizo — who had been holding onto his Hidden Immunity Idol for a record nine Tribal Councils — finally played his idol for himself before the votes were read.
Probst read the votes and revealed Kristina as the 14th person voted out and seventh member of the jury.
2nd Immunity Challenge
Following an interruption due to an address from President Trump, the show picked up at the second and final Immunity Challenge of the night.
The final four were neck and neck as they reached the final portion of the challenge. Soph pulled out a comeback victory and received her first Immunity Challenge win of the season.
"Oh my God, this is a dream!" she said when Probst placed the necklace around her neck.
Fire-Making Challenge

As the winner, Soph had to choose which person to take to the end with her and which two castaways had to face off in the Fire-Making Challenge. She told the other three that they should practice while she contemplated her decision, adding that she didn't want them to plead their cases.

In a confessional, Savannah said she felt betrayed by her "best friend" Soph for not instantly wanting to save her. Rizo tried to remain optimistic and said he had more experience making fire compared to Savannah and Sage. Sage also had a positive mentality as she prepared, telling herself that whatever was meant to happen would happen.

At Tribal Council, Probst said Soph's choice could be a $1 million decision. She announced that she wanted to take Sage to the final three and have her two allies, Savannah and Rizo, make fire to earn the last spot.
While Rizo struggled and repeatedly smothered his fire, Savannah nurtured a strong fire that continued to grow until it burned through the rope, making her the winner.

Rizo became the eighth and final member of the jury. Before leaving, Rizo shared some emotional departing words. "For a little Albanian boy from New York City... to say I have no regrets, to say I made my family proud, to say I made a whole country proud, I truly feel like I left an impact on this game."
He asked to be called by his nickname, "Riz God," as Probst snuffed his torch.
Final Tribal Council

As their final breakfast arrived at camp, Savannah, Sage and Soph reflected on being the first all-female final three in 20 seasons. They also shared some of their favorite moments with each member of the jury.

Next, it was time for Final Tribal Council to begin. Rizo kicked things off by sharing kind words for the three ladies. The remaining members of the jury then posed questions that allowed each finalist to elaborate on their strategies and how they outwitted, outlasted and outplayed everyone else.

When asked to name her most strategic move, Soph said she built strong connections outside of her trio that helped her social game. Savannah recalled a conversation with jury member Sophie Segreti where she pitched working together. Sage mentioned her move to vote out Sophie over Savannah.

For their final pitches, Soph noted that she had been to 12 Tribal Councils and voted out more people than anyone else. Savannah said she successfully dodged the most bullets because she was adaptable, prioritized key relationships and dominated in Immunity Challenges. Sage said she had an important social component to her game that worked hand in hand with her strategic game, allowing her to build close friendships.
And the Winner Is…

"The jury has made their decision. I'll read the votes," Probst said. After three votes were revealed, each woman had a vote each. But as he continued to read the votes, Savannah's name appeared again and again. Savannah was crowned the winner of Season 49.
The cast all toasted with champagne as Probst kicked off the after show.
After Show and Final ‘Survivor’ Season 50 Contestants Revealed

During the after show, Savannah said she felt "imposter syndrome" the whole season and it was a "larger than life feeling" to win the game. "I don't even know what to say because I've never experienced anything like this before. It's a crazy feeling," she added.

In the final moments of the episode, Probst introduced the first trailer for "Survivor" Season 50. At the start of the clip, the host is shown speaking to all the returning players. He tells them he expects them all to give "everything" they have to win.
The chaotic trailer also mentioned that Zac Brown, Billie Eilish, Jimmy Fallon and MrBeast will impact the game in some way.
And with that, Season 49 is over and Season 50 is just a couple months away. See the complete Season 50 cast, below.

Jenna Lewis-Dougherty from Season 1 (Borneo) and Season 8 (All-Stars)Colby Donaldson from Season 2 (The Australian Outback), Season 8 (All-Stars) and Season 20 (Heroes vs. Villains)Stephenie LaGrossa Kendrick from Season 10 (Palau) Season 11 (Guatemala) and Season 20 (Heroes vs. Villains) Cirie Fields from Season 12 (Panama-Exile Island) Season 16 (Micronesia — Fans vs. Favorites), Season 20 (Heroes vs. Villains) and Season 34 (Game Changers)Ozzy Lusth from Season 13 (Cook Islands), Season 16 (Micronesia — Fans vs. Favorites) Season 23 (South Pacific) and Season 34 (Game Changers)Benjamin “Coach” Wade from Season 18 (Tocantins — The Brazilian Highlands) Season 20 (Heroes vs. Villains) and Season 23 (South Pacific) Aubry Bracco from Season 32 (Kaôh Rōng — Brains vs. Brawn vs. Beauty), Season 34 (Game Changers) and Season 38 (Edge of Extinction)Chrissy Hofbeck from Season 35 (Heroes vs. Healers vs. Hustlers)Christian Hubicki from Season 37 (David vs. Goliath)Angelina Keeley from Season 37 (David vs. Goliath)Mike White from Season 37 (David vs. Goliath)Rick Devens from Season 38 (Edge of Extinction)Jonathan Young from Season 42 Dee Valladares winner of Season 45Emily Flippen from Season 45Quintavius “Q” Burdette from Season 46Tiffany Ervin from Season 46Charlie Davis from Season 46Genevieve Mushaluk from Season 47Kamilla Karthigesu from Season 48Kyle Fraser winner of Season 48Joseph Hunter from Season 48Rizo Velovic from Season 49Savannah Louie winner of Season 49

title: The Oscars Are Headed to YouTube After ABC Deal Ends
summary: The Academy Awards are moving to YouTube starting in 2029, the film academy announced Wednesday, marking a new era for Hollywood’s leading awards show and a mainstay of network television for decades
story: The Academy Awards are moving to YouTube starting in 2029, the film academy announced Wednesday, marking a new era for Hollywood’s leading awards show and a mainstay of network television for decades.

The deal between the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and YouTube will start with the 101st Oscars ceremony in 2029 and run through 2033. The telecast has aired live on ABC since the 1970s.

“We are thrilled to enter into a multifaceted global partnership with YouTube to be the future home of the Oscars and our year-round Academy programming,” Academy CEO Bill Kramer and Academy President Lynette Howell Taylor said in a joint statement.

“The Academy is an international organization, and this partnership will allow us to expand access to the work of the Academy to the largest worldwide audience possible — which will be beneficial for our Academy members and the film community,” Kramer and Taylor said.

The two academy leaders said the partnership would “leverage YouTube’s vast reach and infuse the Oscars and other Academy programming with innovative opportunities for engagement while honoring our legacy.”

The deal symbolizes YouTube’s growing dominance in the television and video ecosystem — and Hollywood’s recognition of digital media’s power. The platform, which is owned by the technology behemoth YouTube, represented the largest share of U.S. streaming television viewing last month, according to Nielsen, a leading measurement firm.
Oscars ratings have generally declined since peaking in 1998, the year “Titanic” conquered the ceremony, winning 11 trophies and helping draw in 55 million viewers.

The most recent telecast brought in nearly 20 million viewers — a slight improvement over Covid-era installments, but still a fraction of the audience that tuned in for the ceremony at the height of its commercial and cultural power.

“The Oscars are one of our essential cultural institutions, honoring excellence in storytelling and artistry,” YouTube CEO Neal Mohan said in a statement. “Partnering with the Academy to bring this celebration of art and entertainment to viewers all over the world will inspire a new generation of creativity and film lovers while staying true to the Oscars’ storied legacy.”

The ceremony — including red carpet coverage, behind-the-scenes programming — will be available live and for free to viewers around the world, as well as to YouTube TV subscribers in the United States, according to the academy.
This story originally appeared on NBCNews.com.

title: Tonight's 'Survivor' Finale Will Be Interrupted by a Presidential Address. But for How Long?
summary: What time is the Survivor finale on? How long will the interruption be?
story: The season finale of “Survivor,” scheduled to air Dec. 17, will feature a bit of a hitch when President Trump will interrupt the broadcast to deliver a primetime address to the nation.
The final episode of the 49th season of the long-running reality TV staple is scheduled to run for three hours, but the president’s speech will bump the timeline for viewers.
There are five castaways remaining in the quest to outwit, outplay and outlast each other for the $1 million grand prize:

Kristina Mills, 36, Edmond, Oklahoma, MBA career coachRizo Velovic, 25, Yonkers, New York, tech salesSage Ahrens-Nichols, 30, Olympia, Washington, clinical social workerSavannah Louie, 31, Atlanta, former reporterSophi Balerdi, 27, Miami, entrepreneur
Kristina Mills, 36, Edmond, Oklahoma, MBA career coach
Rizo Velovic, 25, Yonkers, New York, tech sales
Sage Ahrens-Nichols, 30, Olympia, Washington, clinical social worker
Savannah Louie, 31, Atlanta, former reporter
Sophi Balerdi, 27, Miami, entrepreneur
Here’s wat you need to know about how to watch the “Survivor” finale.
What time is the 'Survivor' finale?
The “Survivor” finale will air Dec. 17 at 8 p.m. ET/PT on CBS.
When will the 'Survivor' finale be interrupted?

“CBS News will air a Special Report for President Donald J. Trump’s live primetime address to the nation from the White House, Wednesday, Dec. 17 at 9:00 p.m. ET,” Paramount, which owns CBS, said in a statement.

The schedule on the CBS website lists the “Survivor” finale starting at 8 p.m. ET, with the president’s speech beginning at 9 p.m. ET and a resumption of the finale at 9:22 p.m. ET, at which point it will run for two more hours, concluding at 11 p.m. ET.
When will the 'Survivor' finale return?
The episode will continue after the president finishes his speech.

CBS says the finale “will resume where it left off immediately following the president’s address for Eastern and Central Time Zone viewers on the CBS Television Network and air in its entirety. Check your local listings for more details.”
It should be noted no other time zones were mentioned.

title: Willie Shares How He Got to Meet Taylor Swift — And Why Jenna Missed Out
summary: Willie Geist just lived Jenna Bush Hager’s wildest dream, and she now has a major case of FOMO
story: Willie Geist just lived Jenna Bush Hager’s wildest dream, and she now has a major case of FOMO.
While appearing as a guest co-host on TODAY with Jenna & Friends Dec. 17, Willie shared a photo of himself meeting Taylor Swift at a screening for the singer’s “End of an Era” docuseries.
The six-part Disney+ documentary gives fans a behind-the-scenes look at what it took to put together Swift’s iconic “Eras Tour.”

“It’s amazing. If you’ve been to the show, or even if you haven’t been, what went into making that show and pulling it off every night and everything they went through over the course of the tour, it’s incredible,” Willie explained.
The Sunday TODAY host had attended an “Eras Tour” concert with his daughter, so when he was invited to a screening of the docuseries, he jumped at the opportunity to check it out.

“So you go to the screening room downtown in New York. We’re sitting there getting ready to watch the show. Door opens. Taylor Swift walks in the room to thank everyone for coming. Not only that, she sat with us for the entire show, two episodes, and all of her dancers from the tour — including Kam (Saunders) — were all there,” Willie said.
“Kam was there?” Jenna asked.

“Kam was there — and they’re all cheering for each other when they see their friends on the screen because a lot of the series is about them. She highlights not just her but all the people in the show,” Willie said.
After the screening ended, Willie got a special opportunity to meet Swift.

“She was nice enough to take a couple of pictures with some people, and I posted it (on Instagram) because the series was great,” Willie said. “And wow, people really respond to a Taylor Swift photo.”
Turns out, Jenna had the opportunity to go too, but had to turn down the invite. She blamed it on Jenna & Friends’ “mother,” aka executive producer Talia Parkinson-Jones.

“We had a lot of stuff going on that day, a lot of work stuff, so I wrote my mother, Talia Parkinson-Jones, our boss, and I said, ‘Is there any way — please, mother! — is there any way I can move things around?’ And she wrote back, ‘Gosh, I really wish I could say yes, but the answer is no,’” she recalled.
Naturally, Jenna was a little jealous to hear about Willie’s experience at the screening.
“So when you’re telling me all these things, and even when I saw that Instagram, the FOMO was deep,” she said.
“It hurts, doesn’t it?” Willie quipped.
“I mean, she was looking out for the show, but that was my chance,” Jenna said.
“Well, hopefully you’ll have more chances,” he said.
“That was my chance to hang out with Taylor,” Jenna added.
Willie and Jenna then agreed that maybe Swift should just visit Jenna & Friends and Sunday TODAY
“That’s a good package put together,” Willie said.
“Let’s put the pitch together,” Jenna said. “But anyway, Taylor, I love you, and I’m sorry I wasn’t able to come. My mother told me I couldn’t.”

title: 'Emily in Paris' Is Almost Back! Here's When Season 5 Premieres
summary: What time does Emily in Paris return to Netflix in Season 5? When does the new season of Emily in Paris premiere? Here's how to watch Emily in Paris on December 18.
story: Emily Cooper is about to live la dolce vita in Season 5 of "Emily in Paris."
The hit Netflix series returns to the streaming service for another highly anticipated batch of episodes this week, and finds the fashionable expat living it up in Rome.
Before Season 5 premieres, we're breaking down everything you need to know before tuning in.
What Time Does ‘Emily in Paris’ Season 5 Land on Netflix?
All 10 episodes of "Emily in Paris" Season 5 will premiere globally on Netflix on Thursday, Dec. 18 at 12:01 a.m. PT, so about 3 a.m. ET.
What Will Happen in Season 5 of 'Emily in Paris'?
At the end of Season 4, Emily (Lily Collins) found herself in Rome visiting her new love interest, a handsome Italian named Marcello (Eugenio Franceschini).
Emily's boss, Sylvie (Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu), was determined to take on Marcello's family company as a client for Agence Grateau so she crashed the trip.
Ultimately, the family agreed to give the PR agency a try and Sylvie asked Emily to stay in Rome to run the account and head Agence Grateau's new Rome office.
A trailer for Season 5 shows Emily enjoying her new life in Rome and mixing business with pleasure with Marcello by her side.
Emily started her European journey in Paris and the trailer hints that she'll be returning to Paris at some point this season as Sylvie says, "I need my Emily in Paris."

Emily may be happy with Marcello, but her on again, off again relationship with Gabriel (Lucas Bravo) is ever present, and the French chef makes an appearance in the trailer as he hugs Emily at a train station.
Meanwhile, Emily's ex Alfie (Lucien Laviscount) and her bestie Mindy (Ashley Park) seem to be getting cozy in one scene as they nearly lock lips.
Who's Returning for Season 5?

Camille Razat, who played Gabriel's ex Camille in Seasons 1 to 4, announced that she was leaving the show earlier this year. However, many familiar faces will return for Season 5, including the following:

title: 'The Voice' Season 28 Winner Is Crowned. Find Out Who Won
summary: “The Voice” Season 28 officially has a winner. After a two-night live finale, one artist and coach won the season.
story: “The Voice” Season 28 officially has a winner.

All season long, contestants have been vying for a spot on coaches Michael Bublé, Snoop Dogg, Niall Horan and Reba McEntire’s teams. Last week, four of the six finalists were officially announced, while the last two additional contestants — chosen by viewers — were revealed during the Dec. 15 episode.

Heading into the finale, each coach had at least one singer in the game: Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba), Aiden Ross (Team Niall), Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé), Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop), Max Chambers (Team Bublé) and Dek of Hearts (Team Niall).

Host Carson Daly welcomed special guests and past winners to the stage over the two nights, as well as the final six artists, who delivered their best performances in hopes of being crowned “The Voice” Season 28 winner in the Dec. 16 episode.
Read the two-part recap and find out the winner, below.
What Happened During ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Part 1?
During the Monday, Dec. 15 episode, 14-year-old Max Chambers from Team Bublé and trio Dek of Hearts from Team Niall were revealed as the final two singers competing in the finale.
Here is what they all performed:

Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Fishin’ in the Dark” by Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and “Let It Go” by James Bay.Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang Forrest Frank’s “Your Way’s Better” and Whitney Houston’s “One Moment In Time.”
Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Fishin’ in the Dark” by Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and “Let It Go” by James Bay.
Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang Forrest Frank’s “Your Way’s Better” and Whitney Houston’s “One Moment In Time.”

Team Reba’s Aubrey Nicole sang “‘Til You Can’t“ by Cody Johnson and “The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia,” originally sung by Vicki Lawrence and re-recorded by McEntire in 1991.Team Bublé’s Jazz McKenzie sang “Against All Odds” by Phil Collins and “Drivers License” by Olivia Rodrigo.Team Niall’s Aiden Ross sang “Golden Hour” by JVKE and “The Winner Takes It All” by ABBA.Team Snoop’s Ralph Edwards sang Foreigner’s “I Want to Know What Love Is” and Bruno Mars’ “Locked Out of Heaven.”
Team Reba’s Aubrey Nicole sang “‘Til You Can’t“ by Cody Johnson and “The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia,” originally sung by Vicki Lawrence and re-recorded by McEntire in 1991.
Team Bublé’s Jazz McKenzie sang “Against All Odds” by Phil Collins and “Drivers License” by Olivia Rodrigo.
Team Niall’s Aiden Ross sang “Golden Hour” by JVKE and “The Winner Takes It All” by ABBA.
Team Snoop’s Ralph Edwards sang Foreigner’s “I Want to Know What Love Is” and Bruno Mars’ “Locked Out of Heaven.”
What Happened During ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Part 2?

Eliminated contestants, along with artists like XG, Khalid, Riley Green, Zac Brown, Noah Cyrus, Neal Schon and Journey, and the coaches took the stage. “The Voice” Season 26 winner Sofronio Vasquez also delivered a special performance.

For the second night of the finale, the final contestants got the chance to perform with their coach. Unfortunately, due to health issues and doctor’s orders, Horan was unable to sing with his finalists. McEntire stepped in to perform with Dek of Hearts, while past Team Niall Season 23 winner Gina Miles sang with Ross.
Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Santa Claus Is Coming to Town” with McEntire.Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang “Blue Christmas” with his coach.
Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Santa Claus Is Coming to Town” with McEntire.

title: When and How to Watch 'The Voice' Season 28 Finale
summary: 'The Voice' Season 28 finale takes place Monday Dec. 15, 2025. Find out how to watch on NBC, stream online, and what time both nights air.
story: Season 28 of ‘The Voice” is almost coming to an end.

This season has been jam-packed with powerhouse performances and emotional eliminations since its Sept. 22 premiere. Now, the competition's top six contestants are delivering their final performances in hopes of being crowned the winner.
The first four final contestants were announced last week. Two additional contestants — chosen by viewers — were revealed during the part one live finale on Dec. 15.
The results of the voting will be revealed tonight, Dec. 16, during the star-studded finale episode, which features performances by girl group XG and singer Khalid.

Only one artist — and that artist's coach — will be crowned the winner. Will two-time champion coaches Michael Bublé or Niall Horan win for the third time? Or will they be bested by one of their fellow judges, Reba McEntire or Snoop Dogg?
Here's everything to know about the Season 28 finale.
What Time Does ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Air?
Part one of the two-night finale of “The Voice” aired at 9 p.m. ET on Dec. 15. The second final episode will air also at 9 p.m. ET on Dec. 16.
Where to Watch ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale
Viewers can watch the episodes live on NBC. Each episode will be available to stream the day after it airs on Peacock.
Ahead of the winner being announced on Tuesday's episode, a special finale pre-show will air featuring Ariana Madix and Dylan Efron.
The special will start at 8 p.m. ET on NBC and also stream the following day on Peacock. Madix and Efron will break down Monday's performances and speak with the finalists.
Both NBC and Peacock are owned by NBCUniversal, TODAY’s parent company.
Who Is Competing in the Finale?
Four of the final contestants were announced during the Playoff rounds, while the final two were revealed on Dec. 15.
Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba)Aiden Ross (Team Niall)Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé) Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop).Dek of Hearts (Team Niall)Max Chambers (Team Bublé)
Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba)
Aiden Ross (Team Niall)
Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé)
Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop).
Dek of Hearts (Team Niall)
Max Chambers (Team Bublé)
What’s Going to Happen During ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale?
The live two-part finale kicked off with the show’s top six contestants pulling out all the stops for their final vocal performances.

XG will perform their brand-new song “Gala” during one of the nights. There will also be guest performances by former “The Voice” winner Sofronio and Neal Schon and Journey on Dec. 16, as well as Zac Brown, Riley Green and Noah Cyrus.

Fans have been voting for who they believe the winner should be at NBC.com/VoiceVote or on the official “Voice” app. Whoever wins the most votes will be crowned Season 28’s winner during the live Dec. 16 episode.

title: Golden Globe Swag Bags Are Worth 'Just Under $1 Million.' What's In Them?
summary: What's in the 2026 Golden Globes swag bags? See a complete list and see all 35 items included, plus why they're worth just under $1 million.
story: The recipients of the 2026 Golden Globes won't be the only winners in the building.

A swag bag worth nearly $1 million will not only go to the winners of the coveted trophies, but also the presenters at the annual ceremony. It's a slight reduction from the 2025 bag, which was valued at $1 million.
Once again, the luxury lifestyle magazine Robb Report has curated what it has dubbed "The Ultimate Gift Bag" for the event, which has nearly doubled in value in the last two years.
The luxury swag bag will be given out to the winners and presenters at the 83rd annual Golden Globes, which will air live at 8 p.m. ET on Jan. 11 on CBS and stream on Paramount+.

The 2026 edition features nearly double the amount of luxury travel getaways compared to last year's bag. It features 35 items overall between travel experiences, wellness goodies and wine, spirits and cigars.

“From an expanded slate of global getaways to standout moments in wellness, beauty, and spirits, recipients have the opportunity to create a luxury experience that feels entirely their own," Luke Bahrenburg, President of Robb Report and Head of Luxury Sales at PMC, said in a news release. "Every detail reflects our commitment to celebrating the best in class, bringing together remarkable destinations and rare, indulgent finds to create an unforgettable gifting experience.”
Here's what to know about the 2026 version of the Golden Globes swag bag.
Who will receive the gift bag?
The winners and the presenters at the 83rd annual ceremony will each receive a bag containing the 35 offerings available on a first-come, first-served basis.
What is included in the gift bag?
Packed insider Atlas Bespoke’s Signature Duffel Bag is a gift book detailing all 35 of offerings included in the gift bag.

The most exclusive of the travel offerings, which are available to only one recipient each, are a six-night stay across luxury lodges Flockhill, ROKI and Minaret in New Zealand worth $31,307, and a three-night stay at The Estate Villa in Montego Bay, Jamaica, valued at $30,000.

All winners and presenters are eligible for all offerings in this year’s collection, and the items available to a limited number of recipients are given out on a first-come, first-served basis, according to the Golden Globes.

For the luxury car enthusiasts, one recipient will be allowed to test drive high-end vehicles at The Concours Club in Boca Raton, Fla., in a perk worth $31,400. One recipient will also be awarded two tickets to the Robb Report's Car of the Year competition.

Another prize exclusive to one recipient will be nine ultra-rare bottles of French wine from the Bordeaux winery Liber Pater that are valued at $210,000. Two tickets to the Jubilee at the Liber Pater estate in Bordeaux, valued at $117,000, will also be given to one recipient.

Other luxury travel options available to winners and presenters include a three-night stay at a beachfront villa in San Jose del Cabo, Mexico ($25,000), a five-day luxury yacht trip in Indonesia ($60,000), a two-night stay at an undersea residence on Conrad Maldives Rangali Island ($70,000), a three-night stay at an exclusive Hilton property in the Maldives ($80,000), and a four-nigh stay at a luxury hotel in Bali, Indonesia ($5,800).
Recipients will also be gifted a host of high-end skincare, haircare and perfume products, a rental experience at an ultra-private gym and massages at a pair of Waldorf Astoria locations.
Also included are a bottle of Cygnet 22 and 77 ($500) and a six-bottle case of whiskey from Isle of Harris Distillery ($1,080).

title: What Time Does 'Fallout' Season 2 Premiere? How to Watch

story: Last year's season 1 debut of Prime Video's "Fallout" was an incredible success, becoming the streaming service's most successful program according to Nielsen’s "The Gauge" report in April 2024.
The sci-fi drama follows Los Angeles residents trying to survive after a nuclear war turned the city post-apocalyptic.
With the anticipation for Season 2 so high, Prime Video has an early holiday gift for fans and will release the season's premiere earlier than expected.
Here's everything you need to know to stream the upcoming season of "Fallout."
When does 'Fallout' Season 2 premiere?

You can see the premiere at Tuesday, December 16, at 6 p.m. PT / 9 p.m. ET now, all thanks to "fan demand," per a press release.
What time do 'Fallout' episodes come out?
While the season premiere will release on a Tuesday, fans can expect the rest of the seasons' episodes to premiere on Prime Video Wednesdays at 12am PT / 3am ET.

title: Stars of ‘Stand by Me’ and ‘The Princess Bride’ React to Rob Reiner’s Death
summary: Stars of "The Princess Bride" and "Stand by Me" reacted to director Rob Reiner’s death, sharing what he meant to them.
story: Rob Reiner’s death has reverberated among his fans and the scores of actors he worked with in his roster of legendary movies.
Reiner, 78, and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found dead Dec. 14 in their Los Angeles home, according to police. Their son Nick has been arrested on suspicion of murdering them.

Reiner, the son of comedy icon Carl Reiner, rose to fame in the 1970s on “All in the Family” before making his mark as a filmmaker. He leaves behind a roster of movies that have entertained and moved fans for decades.

Reiner also had an ability to showcase undiscovered, young talent. Robin Wright made her film debut in 1987's “The Princess Bride,” which also starred Fred Savage before viewers were introduced to him in 1988 in “The Wonder Years.” “Stand by Me,” released in 1986, featured Wil Wheaton, Jerry O'Connell, Kiefer Sutherland and John Cusack before they were household names. Stars of those movies were stunned by his death. Take a look at how they remembered Reiner.
"The Princess Bride"
“No words…” he captioned a Dec. 15 Instagram post showing a black-and-white photo of their chairs from the film’s set.

“I am deeply shocked and devastated. I cannot begin to imagine what the family is experiencing or what they will have to endure in the months and years ahead,” she said in a Dec. 15 statement to NBC News.

“It is truly heartbreaking. Rob was one of the most loving, compassionate, and kind people I have ever known. He was an extraordinary director and the impact he had on me has stayed with me throughout my career. My heart goes out to his family and loved ones during this incredibly difficult time.”

“He found me in a casting room in downtown Chicago and gave me the opportunity to be a part of something that has become so much bigger than anyone could have ever imagined,” he captioned a Dec. 15 Instagram photo of him as a child with Reiner.
“Who knew those two weeks in a bedroom set on the Shepperton Studio lot would last forever? His work was a gift to us all and I feel lucky to have been a part of it.”
“Changed my life. Rest in peace, Rob and Michele,” he captioned a photo of the film’s cast on Instagram Dec. 15.
“The tragedy of Rob and Michelle’s deaths are incomprehensible,” he wrote Dec. 15 on Instagram alongside a pair of photos of Reiner, including one of the director giving him a kiss on the cheek.

“I’m hearing Rob’s voice telling us all to do more, to repair the human soul, to repair our hearts, to repair our country, to repair our world, to keep fighting, to keep living for every soul taken from this earth. We must raise our voices for them. I’ll continue to try and follow Rob’s example as an artist and a humanitarian. I hope you do too.

“I don’t know what else to do other than try to cherish every moment we are alive, to be of service to every aspect of our existence and to never give up. When feeling lost one thing I might ask is ‘What would Rob do?’ and then do it.
“Stand by Me”
“Generation X grew up with Rob,” Wheaton wrote in a Dec. 15 blog post on his website.

“We watched him on All in the Family when we were little, and as we came of age, he made movies about our lives as we were living them: movies about growing up, falling in and out of love, about seeing the goodness that exists inside every single person, if only they are open to it. He told us stories about the strength of the human spirit, and he made us laugh. Oh, how he made us laugh.”
Wheaton said he didn’t interact often with Reiner, but his impact was profound.

“I only really knew Rob Reiner for one summer, in 1985, when we made Stand By Me. We only saw each other a handful of times in the last 40 years, and outside of those rare meetings, we only spoke a couple of times. Even though I haven’t spoken to him in years, I will miss him forever.” Eagle-eyed fans will note the “I will miss him forever” line is what the adult version of Wheaton’s character wrote in his story as “Stand by Me” drew to a close.
Wheaton also wrote that he had intended to reunite with Reiner to celebrate the film’s 40th anniversary.

“I was hoping that we would see each other next year, at something celebrating Stand By Me turning 40, so I could see him and properly thank him for everything he gave me — in my career, sure (it only exists because of Rob), but in my life, as well,” he wrote.

“Love you, Rob. Sincerely,” O’Connell captioned a throwback photo of the two of them on Instagram Dec. 15. Fans will no doubt recognize the “sincerely” as a reference to the word O’Connell’s character, Vern, often says throughout the film.

“ROB WAS A HERO 2 MANY, A GR8 DIRECTOR 2 THOSE WHO HAD THE LUCKY CHANCE 2 WORK W HIM, AN AMAZING COMEDIC ACTOR & WRITER, AN AMAZING FATHER 2 THE BEST OF HIS ABILITIES, & A GR8 LOYAL SON 2 HIS OWN FAMOUS FATHER! BUT THAT SUMMER IN 1985, 40 YEARS AGO THIS YR, ON THE SET OF #STANDBYME HE WAS ALL OF R FATHERS THAT SUMMER!” he wrote on Instagram Dec. 15.

“Like so many my heart was broken when I heard the news about Rob Reiner and his wonderful wife, Michele,” he captioned a Dec. 15 Instagram post with a photo of Reiner and Phoenix at work on “Stand by Me.”
“Rob was one of the kindest gentleman I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with. When I was very young he gave me an opportunity that changed my life, and I will forever be grateful.”

“What made Rob a great man — was not his prodigious talents as an actor director writer producer — it was his huge heart, his endless generosity and his decency and humanity that made him great,” Cusack wrote Dec. 15 on X.

“He had soul — and saw the soul in others . He loved justice . Gave me my break in the business and took care of me like a son. A mensch in every sense . Honored to work with him on his second and third films — sure thing and stand by me — Love you Rob.”
King, who wrote “The Body,” the story that was the basis for “Stand by Me,” mourned the death of Reiner, who also directed “Misery,” which was based on King’s book of the same name.

“I’m horrified and saddened by the death of Rob Reiner and Michele. Wonderful friend, political ally, and brilliant filmmaker (including 2 of mine). Rest in peace, Rob. You always stood by me,” he wrote Dec. 15 on X.

title: Who Is Anthony Geary's Husband, Claudio Gama?
summary: Anthony Geary married his husband, Claudio Gama, in 2019. Here's what to know about their relationship and cat, Max.
story: Iconic soap opera star Anthony Geary passed away on Dec. 14 at the age of 78. He is survived by his husband, Claudio Gama.
Gama first shared the news with TV Insider, offering the following statement.
"It was a shock for me and our families and our friends. For more than 30 years, Tony has been my friend, my companion, my husband,” he said.
Geary passed away from complications from a scheduled medical procedure he had undergone three days before his death. The actor's representatives confirmed news of his death to NBC News on Dec. 15.
Geary, who appeared on “General Hospital” for decades as Luke Spencer, retired from the soap opera in 2015 and mostly avoided the spotlight.
Below, we're sharing everything to know about his life with Gama.
Geary and Gama Were Together for Over 30 Years

Gama reflected on their decades together in an Instagram video posted in February 2025. In the short clip, Gama spoke to the couple's cat and said he "finally said yes" to Geary's marriage proposal six years ago.
Geary Lived Together with Gama in Amsterdam
After retiring from "General Hospital" in 2015, Geary moved to Amsterdam with his longtime love.
While speaking with Soap Opera Digest in 2003, Geary opened up about his quiet life overseas.

“I live in the city (Amsterdam) that I’ve always wanted to live in my whole life and I have somebody who loves me and I have a life now, that I didn’t have before, no matter how many fan letters or Emmys or how many pages of dialogue to learn. I didn’t have what I have now. So, everything happened at the right time, I guess,” he said.
They Shared a Cat Named Max
Geary and Gama's cat, Max, appears in many of Gama's Instagram posts.
Recently, Gama shared a video of the cat, who "had to check the tree" when the couple decorated their Christmas tree.
Gama Regularly Posted About His Life With Geary
Over the last few years, Gama has given Geary's fans a look into his life in Amsterdam via Instagram.
Gama also shares updates about his life and travels on his blog, MMaxi Travels Around The World.
